replies.bodyText:
We have to handle at least 3 exception types here (Interrupted, for sleep, URISyntax, and IO) - and so I guess rethrow each type? Or is there a new exception type you think I should throw?
Unlike the provider classes, this one is OK to change in terms of exception usage since it isn't currently used by anything (presumably the REST API can use it in future), and doesn't implement any superclasses.
If you want me to rethrow each exception type in its own catch, that's fine. If you want me to use Exception, that's fine too. There must be one that works best though... HttpResponseException?

timeline.bodyText: Did the lookup "fail", it could be that there are no responses ?
timeline.author: KevinVdV

replies.bodyText:
This is a true "failure" in the sense of an unexpected error. In this case "responses" is a linked list of each individual SHERPAResponse objects, not the list of items included in the JSON response. (because we're chaining some queries for multiple ISSNs).
Even an "empty" API response should still be represented in a valid SHERPAResponse object.
replies.author: kshepherd

replies.bodyText: You are correct, resolving.
replies.author: KevinVdV

timeline.bodyText: Would it be possible to log the response body as well ? (Not sure if this possible)
timeline.author: KevinVdV

replies.bodyText:
It's not easily possible here, but what I've done is logged the error message (created upstream when error was set to true in the SHERPAResponse object), and also logged the response body in the SHERPAService and Data Providers if they ever encounter a response code that isn't HttpStatus.SC_OK
See commit: fdc5a3f2
